newsitem.title: USA: Polygram planning U.S. music exec changes - source.
newsitem.headline: Polygram planning U.S. music exec changes - source.

text.p: PolyGram NV's U.S. unit is planning to reorganize management ranks in its U.S. music operations, according to a source close to Polygram.

A spokeswoman for the company said Friday the company had no comment on a report in the Wall Street Journal that a reorganization was underway. "We're not commenting," a spokeswoman at PolyGram Holdings Inc said.

A source in the U.S. unit, however, said that discussions are ongoing that could result in Danny Goldberg, the president of its Mercury Records unit, moving into a broader role, overseeing several U.S. music labels.
The source said an announcement could come as soon as late next week.
The Journal reported on Friday that under a reorganization, Andre Harrell, the chief of Motown Records, would report to Goldberg.
Polygram U.S. pop labels include A&M, Motown, Island, and Mercury; Deutsche Grammaphon, Decca-London and Philips for classical; Verve in jazz; and about two dozen small boutique labels.
